data.title: Index signature parameter does not accept redefined valid types
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro - 64 bits

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create an alias type for string
2. Create an index signature parameter using the new type

This makes the spellcheck fail in the parameter name for the index because "An index signature parameter type must be 'string' or 'number'"

`
var d1: { [id: string]: {}; } = {} // Spellcheck Ok

type otherString = string;

var d2: { [id: otherString]: {}; } = {} // Spellcheck complains about 'id'
`

data.title: Test JSON intellisense improvements
data.body:
- [x] @isidorn os x

In JSON documents that have a schema associated (e.g. package.json, settings.json) I added suggestions if we only know the type of a property, but don't have any defaults or enums in the schema: New object, new array, new string....
The goal is to avoid the textual proposals that are (IMO) confusing.
- test that the proposals show up
- test that they apply well (enter template mode)
- test that they don't confuse

In JSON documents that have no schema associated:
- add a completion proposal for $schema (top level of an object)
  In JSON documents that have schema or no schema associated:
- proposals for $schema values

data.title: [terminal] Copy action enabled on empty selection, but copy doesn't work
data.body:
Testing #9723

Linux, Elementary OS
- Open the terminal
- select some text in the terminal, use copy from the context menu, paste the text: works
- set the focus to the cursor position (no selection), use copy from the context menu, paste the text: still pastes the previous text

-> Maybe the copy menu should not be present (or disabled) if the selection is empty

data.title: Sourcemap remote debugging with break points
data.body:
I tried a whole day to get remote debugging with break points on my VM, but I didn't succeed. I have read all old issues, blog posts and SO. But I still cannot figure out what I've done wrong?

I have a VM running locally on my Mac at host `app.local`. Inside the VM I have a folder `/home/myusername/app`, I have a TS project. Here is my configurations :

``` json
    {
        "compilerOptions": {
            "module": "commonjs",
            "target": "es5",
            "noImplicitAny": true,
            "outDir": "Build",
            "rootDir": ".",
            "experimentalDecorators": true,
            "jsx": "react",
            "reactNamespace": "Element",
            "removeComments": true,
            "forceConsistentCasingInFileNames": true,
            "strictNullChecks": true,
            "noEmitOnError": true,
            "noImplicitThis": true,
            "inlineSourceMap": true,
            "inlineSources": true
        },
        "exclude": [
            "node_modules",
            "vendor"
        ]
    }
```

And here is my `launch.json`:

``` json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "name": "Attach",
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "address": "app.local",
            "port": 5858,
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "localRoot": "${workspaceRoot}",
            "remoteRoot": "/home/myusername/app",
            "restart": true
        }
    ]
}

```

I can see the generated files have inlined source map and inlined sources(I have also tried with non-inlined mapping as well). I start the server `node-dev --debug Build/Start.js`. After that I attach to the process and succeeds. But the problem comes when I try to set a break point â€” it fails?

I have also tried many `remoteRoot` paths to hopefully get the breakpoints working, though failed? I don't think I have a remote idea what I've done wrong at this moment.

data.title: Debug: 'Disconnect' icon should be different than 'Stop'
data.body:
Currently we use the same `Stop` icon for both `Stop` and `Disconnect` actions. It would be more intuitive to use an icon that confers the idea of a _disconnection_ when the `Disconnect` action is in place.

cc @bgashler1

data.title: Confusing documentation for "environment" in launch.json
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1 with C/C++ extension 0.7.1
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce: Open launch.json and hover over "environment":
![bildschirmfoto zu 2016-07-26 09-14-41](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/80071/17129146/ad8f5b5c-5311-11e6-953c-d82ed8d6c60f.png)

I followed the example, but I'm getting `Incorrect type. Expected "array"`. This page https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/debugging says I should use `"env"`, but I guess that's because it's for Node.js debugging and I'm trying to debug a C++ application?

data.title: cursroMove to end of wrapped line in select mode is not selecting the text
data.body: `cursorMove(to:'wrappedLineEnd' select: true)` is not selecting the text.

data.title: [Configuration] Get configuration doesn't return default value if not found.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0-Insider
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Add a new boolean option to contribution list of an extension
2. Run/debug the extension, try fetch the configure by `vscode.workspace.getConfiguration("section").get("optionName",  undefined)`

If user doesn't  set a value for this config in his/her settings.json, the return result of this expression should be `undefined`. While what we get is `false`.

If the config is defined as `number`, this expression will return `null`. If user sets this config explicitly, we can get the correct value.

BTW, it seems we don't have a chance to know whether a Code config, for example `editor.tabSize`, is set by User or Workspace or just default value. It's a potential feature request.

data.title: Vertical margins around lists in jsdoc comments are too large
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
- Open vscode.
- Paste this into a new buffer:

``` ts
interface TypeChecker {
        /**
         * Two types are considered identical when
         *  - they are both the `any` type,
         *  - they are the same primitive type,
         *  - they are the same type parameter,
         *  - they are union types with identical sets of constituent types, or
         *  - they are intersection types with identical sets of constituent types, or
         *  - they are object types with identical sets of members.
         *
         * This relationship is bidirectional.
         * See [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/blob/master/doc/spec.md#3.11.2) for more information.
         */
        isIdenticalTo(a: any, b: any): boolean;
}
```
- Save the file as `example.ts`.
- Mouse over `isIdenticalTo` and see the documentation popup.
- Observe large vertical margins around and within the list.

data.title: Addresses #3690 high-contrast less hacky in editor
data.body:
This pertains to the Monaco editor running in Windows high-contrast mode.

Windows removes all background images in high contrast mode unless a rule like this applied.

data.title: Show some kind of progress for installing large extensions.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1
- OS Version: All

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use the new extensions viewlet to install a large extension
2. Wait, with no progress.

Notes:

We have had a few people request this on our extension page because, it seems, certain regions have been experiencing intermittent slowness or service interruptions. They are requesting that VsCode give them some sort of download/installation status so that they know whether or not there is an issue with the installation.

data.title: Cannot set the value of a watch expression

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VS Code version: 1.3.1

There is no way for the user to assign a value to an item in the watch window.
### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Hit a breakpoint in a C# project with a local variable `i`
2. Add the watch expression `i`
3. Double click or right click on the value
### Expected Result:
- The user enters the edit **value** box
- In the case of right click, the "Set Value" command **appears** in the context menu
### Actual Result:
- The user enters the edit **expression** box
- In the case of right click, the "Set Value" command **does not appear** in the context menu

In order to make it so that the user does not try to assign values to expressions such as `i + j`, the evaluate response should be able to contain some sort of "isEditable" property.

data.title: Type information doesn't appear when hovering over watch expressions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1

Now that the type information goes in the tooltip, there's no place for the user to view the type information for a root-level watch expression, as watch expressions only show the expression's value in their tooltip.
### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Hit a breakpoint
2. Create a watch expression
3. Hover mouse over the name of the watch expression
### Expected Result:
- Tooltip appears with type information like it does in the variables section
### Actual Result:
- Tooltip appears with expression's value

_Note:_ Expanding an expandable watch expression and hovering over the name of a child item gives the type tooltip as expected!

data.title: Recognize .bats as Bash language
data.body:
I write bats (https://github.com/sstephenson/bats) tests using vscode and every time I open the file I set language to `Shell Script (bash)` manually.

May be add .bats to the list so that its language is detected automatically?

data.title: Allow extensions to contribute a view to the navigation pane.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: It would be very useful for extensions to be able to contribute views to the navigation pane / leftmost pane. For instance, a Clojure extension might contribute a tree view of namespaces with symbols as the leaves for project navigation. This would allow a user to jump to a position in a file were a symbol within a namespace was defined.

data.title: [scss] depricated color list is not correct
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.3.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Open a SCSS file
2.  Type body { color: lightgray; }

"lightgray" is red.  It looks like there is some list in extensions/scss/syntaxes/scss.json that calls them "deprecated", but I can see no evidence that these colors have been deprecated, and are in specs as far back as 2011. The link in file doesn't actually point to anything.
